Those  who visit here,  will gain a deeper appreciation of Ho Chi Minh's life long quest for "all" people to be free.

data.formatted_address: 179 Phan Đình Phùng, Phú Nhuận, Thành phố Huế, Thừa Thiên Huế, Vietnam
data.name: An Dinh Palace

reviews.text: My visit to An Dinh Palace in Hue was an unforgettable experience. The palace, with its blend of European and Vietnamese architectural styles, stands as a testament to the city's rich history and cultural heritage. Walking through its ornate halls and rooms, I was struck by the intricate details in the decorations and furnishings, each telling a story of the Nguyen Dynasty's opulence. The well-preserved murals and artifacts provide a fascinating glimpse into the royal lifestyle. The serene gardens surrounding the palace add to its charm, offering a peaceful retreat from the city's hustle and bustle. Overall, An Dinh Palace is a must-visit for anyone interested in history, architecture, and the cultural tapestry of Hue.

Slightly less touristy place to visit in Hue if looking for a break from the crowds. The inside is a little bit restored in some places, the outside garden looked like it could use a little care (could be very pretty if it was kept) and entry was a little steep 50k for what it was but that is true for most of Hue “attractions” in my opinion. Still nice for a look.

I visited An Dinh Palace at 10.30 am and it was really hot. However the beautiful architecture, and French style interiors captivated me. I would recommend it for photo enthusiasts, you will see a lot of people doing photoshoots here! You won't spend more than 1 hour here and the entry fee is 50,000VND per person. Overall it's a good place to click some pictures and spend some time appreciating the creative structure.

I went to this place on my last afternoon in Hue. An admirable place that also has friendly guards. At this location you can take photos to your heart's content because there will be a balcony where you can take photos with the beautiful leaves and sky! Ticket price is 50,000VND per person and 5,000VND for motorbike parking

Lovely place, although it's not well maintained. Kinda disappointed to see such a historical site like this left in an ill-treated state. Many restored wall paints are either unfinished or faded, sections of the building are entirely left unpainted. Despite all of that if you are a history enthusiast I would still recommend you to visit this place. There are still many interesting details that are hidden in plain sight. And also because the tickets are pretty cheap if you buy it in a combo along side with Hue Royal Antiquities Museum (Musé Khai Dinh), only 80k ($3.2) costing as much as two and two third Bún Bò bowls.

data.formatted_address: 32 Đặng Thái Thân, Phú Hậu, Thành phố Huế, Thừa Thiên Huế, Vietnam
data.name: Kiến Trung Palace

reviews.text: The most ornate and the least interesting of all the palatial buildings in the forbidden city. Basically, it's an imitation of a French Chateau with a few Vietnamese details thrown in. What I really did not like about it was the lack of air movement inside. On a hot day it must be sweltering. There is a tiny coffee shop in the west wing of the building which is a plus, but honestly... this building is not that special at all.

A well-preserved palace now filled with lots of artifacts and historical artifacts looking into the 19th century and what an emperor at the time would possess and live like. I enjoyed the large gallery of artifacts with labels to post of them.
It has been opened for tourists since Vietnamese Tet holidays in 2024 after a long time (around 5 years) of reconstruction. It's a great combination of Vietnamese and French styles.
This Palace is mind blowing at the amount of intricate fine detail in all its features and so well preserved after so much time, hope you enjoy the pics

Kiến Trung Palace was built between 1921 and 1923 during the reign of Emporer Khải Định (1885-1925) and served as the living and working space of Bảo Đại, the last emperor of the Nguyễn Dynasty which reined from 1802 to 1945.

The palace is an important historical work, marking a unique and special period that complements the traditional Huế royal design.

Its architecture meets the characteristics of an Indochina-style building with a combination of Asian and European influences. It incorporates elements from three distinct architectural styles - traditional Vietnamese, French and Italian Renaissance - and embodies an era of Western influence in Việt Nam.

It is among the five main palaces of the former royal citadel, along with Thái Hòa, Cần Chánh, Càn Thành, and Khôn Thái. In 1947, the palace was practically destroyed by the war with only its foundations remaining intact.

Investments in the reconstruction of Kiến Trung Palace were significant to rebuild the foundation walls, railing system, front and back yards, and two floors with a height of about 14m, on a construction site of about 975sq.m.

Other small works such as brick pedestals, fountains, cannons, guard houses, and gardens are also part of the investment plan.

The highlight of Kiến Trung Palace lies in the unique colourful patterns inlaid with porcelain in vivid decorative themes to create the soul of the work. The restoration of the porcelain mosaic is about 80 per cent complete and has involved the participation of many skilled and experienced artisans in the field of folk art.

The work began in February 2019 and has entered the final phase. It will help preserve and uphold the UNESCO-recognised Complex of Huế Monuments in the central province of Thừa Thiên-Huế.

Still a peaceful place to see some history and almost no other tourist in site. A lot of trees, which is nice if you want to be immersed in nature.

I felt like traveling to the past by standing in this complex.

It was totally free from tourists. This tomb remains its original way , which will definitely make your visit worth a hundred times than spending a lot to a touristy tomb.

Most of the buildings are under renovation so there's not much to see. The ticket is 50,000 vnd/adult.

We visited on a Saturday but hardly see any other guests. The tomb ground are spacious with lot of trees so you can feel the cool and fresh air.

A pleasant walk around the historical place. The tomb is not very well maintained however the statues around are in good condition. The nearby forest is very beautiful, tomb is surrounded by water and rice fields. Entrance fee is 50vnd but we were allowed to pass without payment.
A worth place to visit to understand the life of Vietnamese during the war. The history is really awesome

data.formatted_address: 75 Lê Huân, Phú Hậu, Thành phố Huế, Thừa Thiên Huế, Vietnam
data.name: Truong Du Pavilion

reviews.text:
There is a cafe and soft drinks sale at the spot, a nice place to stop by after touring the Imperial City

The site also provided the prototype of Hue Imperial City in an ancient time

Today it is a small cafeteria where you can have something cool and rest a little in the fresh air.
The water house, a small pavilion surrounded by a pond 28 meters long and 20 meters wide facing south. It was a place where the king's widow could relax and was built in 1849, for the wife of King Dục Đức.

This is a house located in the architectural complex of Dien Tho Palace, an area reserved for Queen Mothers of the Nguyen Dynasty, nearly 1.8 hectares wide, located in the west of the Imperial Citadel. Du Ta School was built in 1849 to prepare for the grand celebration of Pentecost by Queen Mother Tu Du, mother of King Tu Duc. Ta built on a lovely square lake, 530 m2 wide, on the east side of the main palace, facing south. The structure is in the style of Hue's traditional Ruong house with a square frame (Phuong communal house), a room with four wings, 16 pillars, and a roof covered with green glazed tube tiles. All three east, west and south sides of Truong Du Ta are surrounded by corridors. Later this corridor was removed, the southern part was renovated into a crab shell house called Luong Phong Dinh.

Although the structure is in the style of a beam house with a quite dense column system, the architectural space of this weight house is still very airy because the door system on all 4 sides is very wide, the plank wall system is replaced with bright glass so it stands tall. Even inside the house, people can still clearly observe the outside landscape. Some panels and partitions in the house are meticulously decorated with extremely elaborate carvings and perforations, thus increasing their aesthetic effectiveness.

Overall, in terms of both scale and structural form, Truong Du Ta is only a relatively small and simple architectural work, but in return, because it is placed in a reasonable space, Truong Du Ta creates beauty. Very harmonious and poetic, worthy of being used as a place to "reward and relax" for the Queen Mothers at the Western Palace.
It is now a cafe, where you can take a break and have a drink. Carp bait was sold for 5,000 VND.
Beautiful, peaceful scene. Wooden houses fit the landscape very well. Worth experiencing.

reviews.text: Recommend to make a reservation, but without korean phone number, it is not easy to make reservation.  The truffle mushrooms steam rice is super yummy, must try.  We also tried the braised short rib, which is very tender and soft.

Ok, steak lovers, buckle up, because there’s the perfect spot for you tucked away in Itaewon: Hue 135! I’m telling y’all… this spot takes dry-aged beef to a whole new level. The mastermind behind the magic is none other than Chef Kim Se-kyung. He has truly knocked it out the park. As soon as you walk in, you're like, "This place is CLASSY!" It’s got that luxurious, Gatsby-like vibe, and it totally fits the dining experience. But the real star of the show here is the food. It’s all in the name: 'Hue 休' means 'rest', and '135 degrees' is apparently the sweet spot for cooking meat. And this is the foundation for the steak here – and they nail it. I’m talking next-level flavor and texture from beef that's been aged for weeks before reaching your plate. The chef grills it all up right there in front of you, which is an awesome touch. The non-meat dishes are also all supurb and insanely creative. Now, it's not exactly budget-friendly, but trust me, the experience is worth every penny. Think of it as splurge -- or the perfect spot for a special meal. So, if you're curious about what dry-aged steak really tastes like and ready for a new culinary adventure, run – don’t walk – to Hue 135.
Hidden gem of Dry-aged steakhouse in Seoul. Its tasting course offers various dishes that combine Korean flavor into chef's character!

Best cooked steak I’ve ever had (thanks Da Bin Son!!). Hanwoo doesn’t mess around. The starters were also very tasty and the final after rice set with all the accoutrements really ties it all together.

Wine selection was well catered to it being a steakhouse.

They have a persimmon + cinammon dessert that capped it off PERFECTLY. Will go again whenever I’m next in Seoul.

We had a private room for 4 of us.   We had a selection of 3 aged meets.  The tenderloin was the a beautiful mix of crispy on the outside and tender in the middle.   The strip loin had a wierd taste.  The service was friendly but nothing to dream about.   It is located in a lovely neighbourhood.

Long

After visiting the Citadel, you will exit through this door.

reviews.text:
Suitable for people who want to hide away from the crowded tourist attractions.
This place is quiet and has a stunning view of the river. If you are lucky you might catch a breath taking sunset.
Free, close to the bunker there is a Big blue tower where the view is Amazing.

Trash and ugly development. The two fastest ways that the unmatched natural beauty of Vietnam is being ruined. In my opinion, what made this place special is the natural, pine forest and scenic view. That's destroyed by this tacky development to make it more "touristy" defeating the purpose of why people come here to begin with. The trash literally everywhere just ruins it completely. Wrappers upon wrappers in every cm of this place. My pictures show 1% of how dirty it is. Sad!

One of the top view points in Hue city, perfect place for couples or group of friends.
It’s a hill with full of pine trees, from here, you can sit and take rest, feel the peaceful and easily see many awesome viewpoints of Perfume River.

For the secenic vistas and historical perspective it's a worthwhile place to visit. I was in the first generation cut loose from conscription, so I never had to fight the Vietnamese. For that I owe all the people who fought in, and all those that resisted a war that really wasn't necessary. It was the first of many future wars that enriched the military/industrial complex that Eisenhower warned us about.

It was so busy, that a taxi man asked if we wanted a taxi, my hubby was Iike yeah, He said you need 2 cars, 600,000 dong.

Be careful here

Small station but the red colored that looks nice.
You’ll be surrounded with many taxi drivers so check prices on Grab or any places first then feel free to bargain. The taxi drivers in Hue are not nice, if there’s a chance, they’ll make money from just 5,10K or even more than that!

The ride between Hue  and Da Nang is worth doing via Hai Van Pass

data.formatted_address: Richmond, UK
data.name: Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew

reviews.text:
Beautiful botanic gardens to the west of London. I hadn’t been in several years so decided to come back with my partner on a Sunday when the weather was agreeable.

This place certainly hasn’t lost any of its magic. The entrance is located just a few minutes walk from a couple of stations (Kew Bridge and Kew Gardens). We arrived later in the day and there were no queues. There is a discounted entry rate if you arrive at 16:00, which was great because we still had 4 hours to enjoy the site but the gardens were almost empty. That said, you could easily spend a full day here.

Stunning conservatories housing a range of plants from all corners of the globe. I also really enjoyed the views from above on the Treetop Walkway.

Brilliant way to spend the day. I’ll definitely be back.

Absolutely beautiful. One of the best experiences in London - for both residents and tourists alike. The garden is massive, there is so much to see and do. I visited in summer and would highly recommend it. Be sure to check out the many greenhouses, the pagoda and the rose garden.

An absolute must if you’re visiting (or living) in London! For regulars, I would recommend getting a season pass available online which will allow you to visit all year round for the low, one-off payment.

Such a big place, so much to see. A few minutes walk from the station. No queues when we arrived. Plenty of places to buy food and drinks, the orangery is lovely, inside and out.  The conservatories are amazing and to be able to go up a level and see the from a height. The palace is very interesting as is the Hive, so different and epic. Princess of Wales conservatory is lovely.

Lovely places, I remember coming here when I was little on a school trip. Then came back recently many many years later with my family and they absolutely loved it.

Great views and scenery. Beautiful setting and lovely walks. Great day out with friends or family.

Only reason 4 stars as I wished they had more toilets spread about the place and shops for food snacks and etc.

Definitely one of londons top attractions 👌

So much to see and do!
Made much easier in that one can borrow wheelchairs (manual and scooters) which makes getting around the extensive site much easier if you have any mobility issues. Shame about the planes going over constantly otherwise it would be very peaceful. But we had a great time nonetheless!

data.formatted_address: 09 Đ. Ngô Quyền, Vĩnh Ninh, Thành phố Huế, Thừa Thiên Huế, Vietnam
data.name: ParkView Hotel

reviews.text: Far from 4 stars in Europe.  Overall tired hotel, could have been good in the past but not any more. Spacious rooms, but no central AC and dated PVC joinery that let's all the noise from the street inside. Kudos here - own pool and massage services, but basic breakfast.

During my two-night stay at the hotel, I encountered a few issues:
1. The breakfast was not appealing.
2. The elevator was out of service for 15 minutes and could only accommodate two people and three pieces of luggage. As a result, my colleagues and I had to use the stairs from 5th floor to G floor.
3. The air conditioning unit was noisy.
4. The bellman did not assist with our luggage.
They charged for Service fees and VAT for the fees.
Considering these experiences, I believe that the hotel's rating of four stars is not accurate.
The interior is quite old, the smell of room spray is quite strong, the buffet has a few dishes But the location is convenient for transportation

Booked Park View hotel for my team to attend a conference near the hospital. The facilities is subpar more on the 3* or lower level than what it says is 4*. The staff is hit and miss depending on who is on duty. One staff denied my request to have an additional key, while giving me an attitude for such a request.

In addition, the showers were wet and water overflow each time I take a shower. When asking to see if I can get a late checkout for 1pm, the staffs on duty had an overpowering demeanor and suggested I had to pay 30% of the daily rate for such an extension. I told them it's only an extra hour when I've rented over 4 rooms for two nights, which I was asking to extend 2 rooms for an hour.

Much to my surprise on their customer service level, or lack thereof, the didn't really care much about the customers. They only cared about themselves and the additional fee to charge.

There are other better alternative than Park View. I will not stay nor recommend anyone to stay here.
Very dirty hotel. It smells very bad. Very noisy and old. Dirtiest hotel I have ever been to.

The emart is one of Korea's leading big market brands.
You'll find most of what you want at great prices.  the emart satisfies customers with a variety of items.  At around 9 p.m., discounts on ready-to-cook food and fresh produce begin.  If you use it well, you will be able to solve even simple meals at a better price.  In accordance with the policy to protect small business owners in Korea, large supermarkets in the Seoul area designate the second and fourth Sundays as closed.  Outside of Seoul, the second and fourth Wednesdays are designated as closed days.  Before visiting each E-Mart store, we recommend that you check the operating dates and hours first.  Parking fees are supported depending on the purchase amount, and if you have an E-Mart point membership, you can receive even greater discounts.

The ancient university of Hue where the doctoral exams and such were awarded. A bit neglected ruin but you can imagine the space. No one was there. It’s a short way along the river from the pagoda.
